In my opinion, the Catholic Church could stand to change in a few areas. They've been losing some of their followers, and I think it's due to their often steadfast views on certain topics. For instance, they have strong views on issues like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control, which can seem outdated in the modern world. If they were to adopt a more contemporary mindset, they might not face the same threat to their following.

I've heard a lot of people are starting to turn away from the Catholic Church because they disagree with their stance on these issues. For example, if someone is pro-abortion, they might not feel comfortable in a faith that views abortion as completely wrong. Similarly, if someone supports gay marriage, they may not want to be part of a church that doesn't agree with that.

I'm not sure why the Catholic Church can't ordain women as priests or allow priests to marry, but I think it would be beneficial for both the Church and its followers. It could help the Church appear more modern and relatable, while also giving priests a more balanced life. However, I'm not convinced that these changes would prevent the abuse scandals that have plagued the Church. It's hard to say if married priests or women priests would have made a difference in those situations. Ultimately, I believe that even with these changes, the Church might still face the same issues.

Well, to be honest with you, I'm not one to argue against gay marriage. I mean, I think that whether someone is born with a certain sexual orientation or they choose it, it's not a conscious decision. Therefore, I believe that gay people shouldn't be held accountable for their sexual orientation. It's just wrong to say that a man and a woman can get married, but two people of the same sex can't. I haven't given this topic much thought, but I'd certainly say it's wrong to make such a distinction. It's not as if being gay is a choice, like being straight is for some people. I mean, I was born straight, and others are born gay, and I don't think that's something they should be held responsible for. I don't think it's a legal or moral issue that the federal government should be involved in. It's not about their security or moral concerns, it's just about being who they are. The federal government has no right to interfere with people's lives, especially if they haven't done anything wrong. That's just how they were born, and they shouldn't be punished for that.

It's my belief that gay marriage ought to be legalized. There really isn't a compelling reason not to. People often assert that same-sex couples pose a threat to traditional families, but it's just not that simple. There are so many variables involved that it's impossible to compare the two situations directly. It's like comparing heads and tails; they might look different, but they're both valid sides of the same coin. Furthermore, numerous civil rights are at stake here, such as property taxes and healthcare benefits where a partner can't be listed as next of kin if they're in a same-sex relationship. This seems unfair if you're committed to someone for life. Scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have similar success rates in relationships as heterosexual couples. They just want the same legal document that any couple can receive from the government, a marriage certificate. Church and state involvement shouldn't be an issue when it comes to legalizing marriage. It's like segregation, separate but unequal. Many people also worry about adoption issues and how children in same-sex families will be treated by society. I believe these concerns are overblown. Perhaps, in some cases, children in same-sex families may face challenges, but parenting skills and community involvement aren't affected by sexual orientation. The federal government should step in and legalize gay marriage across all states. The amendment should be reversed to reflect this. However, President Bush has strong religious views that influence his stance on the subject, similar to his views on abortion and stem cell research. Most of the arguments against gay marriage are based on moral grounds, which vary greatly from person to person. It's unethical to impose the morality of one group on the entire country. Many people believe that gay people are psychologically damaged due to childhood trauma or personality defects, but the American Psychological Association has debunked these claims. It's important to listen to institutions that conduct research rather than popular opinion.

Well, first off, I'm working in a hospital pharmacy over the summer. I mean, just because a drug is illegal doesn't mean it has beneficial properties. I mean, we all know that. Having it available for the public? No, absolutely not. But for medicinal purposes? I'd say yes. Just because a drug is illegal doesn't mean it's beneficial. It's not beneficial. That's the thing. There are so many drugs that are illegal but are beneficial, like oxycodone, Vicodin, Percocets, things like that. Those are controlled substances, but we use them all the time because they're beneficial. If you deny that just because there's a taboo around marijuana, then what's the point? You should embrace its beneficial properties, I think.

I mean, it's not similar to alcohol. If you abuse it, alcohol can lead to bad things. But marijuana, if you abuse it, it's a tough one. I'd say, not that you could integrate it. You could let it become legal gradually, but not all at once, because then it would be abused. You gotta remove that taboo around marijuana first, and then people might use it responsibly. People have such a bad image of marijuana because it's an illegal drug. I mean, it's not that bad for you. It's not like heroine or cocaine. If we get rid of that image of marijuana as a horrible thing, then people might be able to use it responsibly, and certainly for medical purposes.

I believe that the church has adapted to suit the twenty-first century, loosening its strictness. As I grew up, I'd attend church every Sunday, dressed to the nines in cute dresses, matching shoes, and a purse. I went to a private school, where I'd see friends at church on weekends. Now, though, they've introduced a teenager mass that lasts just thirty minutes, and people wear more casual attire, especially during summer when they come straight from the beach. Even at morning masses, I see folks in jeans and khakis. I think the church has become more casual overall. As for other changes, I don't know much about the church's politics, but the biggest thing I've noticed is the change in dress code and the introduction of a shorter mass. [OK, regarding the accusations against Catholic priests, do you think these could have been prevented if the church changed, like allowing female priests or priests to marry?] I don't think these things could have been avoided because there are men who become pedophiles even if they're married. It's more about individual predisposition than rules. If they really wanted to practice their faith and be married, they could consider a different faith. [Can you elaborate on your answer?] I think it's more about genetics influencing sexuality. People are born that way, not just from upbringing. I don't think marriage can change that. If the church knew about it and covered it up, that's shameful, but I don't think they always knew. [Do you have any other thoughts about the Catholic Church?] No.

Initially, I was on board with the initial premise, but I believe everyone was still deeply affected by the September 11th attacks, and I think we went into Iraq under false pretenses. There were several reasons that led us into Iraq, including claims that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which have since been proven false.
I find it utterly infuriating that the Bush administration openly lied to the American people and has yet to take responsibility.
Even Colin Powell, who presented the case at the UN, admits he wasn't convinced by the evidence he was presenting at the time.
To me, that's an impeachable offense. They lied to the American people, and I believe they've shown a complete disregard for the Constitution since the September 11th attacks.
It seems they came into office with an intent to go to war, perhaps driven by a desire to expand our energy supply.
I think the Iraq war has gone on long enough, but I'm concerned that withdrawing now could lead to civil war and more deaths.
The alternative seems to be a coalition of nearby nations like Syria and Saudi Arabia to try to restore order, but I'm not convinced that's a good idea in the long term.
Iraq's sovereignty could become a major issue, as the interim government appears to be dissolving. The Parliament isn't effective, and radical factions are vying for control.

I genuinely believe that it's not right to legalize it or for a state to declare it legal. It should be up to the churches, as the Constitution clearly states our separation of church and state. Trying to enforce any rules or power over it would go against the principles already established in our constitution. I think those pushing for it are pitting one church's beliefs against others, as most Catholics and Christians are against it, except for in certain areas like Boston. It's not up to the government to decide what churches should or shouldn't make illegal. Our constitution already provides for religious tolerance. Making an amendment about it would be wrong and contradictory to what's already been established. Plus, it's one of the few amendments that could be used to restrict the people rather than the government. I don't think the federal government or any government should be involved in this issue. The person pushing for this amendment is doing so because it goes against his personal beliefs as a Catholic. His push for an amendment is showing a preference for one religion over others. I truly believe it's up to the churches to decide this matter, not the president or any government official. There's no valid reason for an amendment banning it, as I don't see how it would impact the economy or society negatively. In fact, it might have a positive impact on society.

The war in Iraq
Well
Let me start from the beginning. I don’t believe the government was completely honest with the American people about the war in Iraq. I think they tried to link the invasion of Iraq to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, even though there wasn't a strong connection. They played on the emotions of the American people, and the invasion started in 2003.

I myself am against war, especially preemptive strikes. I think the war in Iraq is similar to the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes. A tremendous amount of American soldiers have died, and the government wasn't prepared for the aftermath. They removed the Iraqi government and tried to implement a democratic one, a process that should have been carefully planned.

I think the government didn't prepare well for the challenges that would follow, and they didn't account for the massive insurgency that would arise. They should have learned from the Vietnam War, where the US faced a similar challenge. The US government made it seem like victory would be swift and easy, which was naive and deceiving.

In the 2004 presidential election, I would have voted for George Bush to finish what he started, but it's difficult to see how we can abandon Iraq now. We can't leave them without their government anymore. It's a tough decision because we’ve been there for so long and there are so many American casualties. But how much is too much to risk for a free democratic Iraq?

Another consideration is why we're not doing this in other countries. It seems to be about oil, and we get oil from Iraq. The government's justification for the war was about weapons of mass destruction, but they were never found. Meanwhile, North Korea has them, and we aren't making any attacks against them. I don't think the US government is being thorough or truthful enough in their decisions.

I just hope the war ends soon and brings peace, but I doubt it.

Let's dive right in. I've always been an advocate for gay marriage, and I believe it should be a personal preference, not something that society or the government should interfere with. I think it's inhumane to deny people rights based on something they have no control over, especially when science shows it might be biological rather than sociological. In my neighborhood, I have a few openly gay couples who live together, and they function just like any other family. They walk their dogs on the street, and it's clear they're happy and loving. But the government, particularly with Bush trying to interpret marriage his way, is being ridiculous. It's like they're trying to play God. I think marriage should be a private, personal matter, not something that needs to be in the public's eye or dictated by the government. It's strange that a guy and a girl can get married in secret in Las Vegas, but if two gay people want to do the same, it makes the news. That's not fair.

You know, when you put something online, it's out there for the world to see. It's a public forum, and you can't control what people think or do with that information. As a Resident Assistant, I've had to deal with this already. When you share something online, it's like you're shouting it from the rooftops. You can't just share any information without thinking about the consequences.

For instance, if you're talking about something dangerous, like blowing something up or planning shootings, someone will definitely take notice. The internet is seen by everyone, so if you're friends with someone on Myspace, they'll see it. Obviously, the school isn't looking at these things, but someone in the community might notice and bring it to the school's attention.

There's no invasion of privacy when something is brought to the school's attention. If you don't want something to be seen, don't put it online. You can't tell people what to think or take seriously. The school officials aren't supposed to be monitoring phone conversations, texts, or IM's, but if something is brought to their attention, they have to take it seriously.

For example, a few months ago, someone overheard something in the school and got worried. They went through the person's Facebook and found something that was meant as a joke but became serious in light of the situation. If something is brought to the school's attention, there's no invasion of privacy, because the information was made public.

Teachers shouldn't be creating accounts under different names and becoming friends with their students. I wouldn't friend my residents on Facebook for the same reason. I don't want to see what they're doing or posting, like going out and drinking. If it's brought to their attention, though, the school has to take it seriously.

I feel like the war has been dragged out far too long. I think the original intent was noble, aiming to restore democracy in another country. However, I believe we've strayed from that purpose. Now, it seems like we're just fighting to prove our status as a superpower. The initial motivations were questionable, involving previous tensions between George Bush Sr. and Saddam Hussein. If the goal was to democratize a country with an unfair political system, that would be a valid reason for the war. However, I think our original objectives have become distorted, and we're now stuck in a conflict with an unclear endgame. We're still at war, not because we must, but because we don't want to retreat without a decisive victory. It's been drawn out for too long. The government there now needs to stand on its own, and we should focus on our own economic struggles. We're spending billions that could be better used on our own issues, like poverty and public infrastructure. The war is a long-term drain on our economy, and there are pressing domestic issues that need our attention. It's time to bring our troops home.

I certainly believe that gender discrimination remains a significant issue in the United States. It’s not just about women; it extends to various fields of work. For instance, women often struggle to ascend to positions that they qualify for, as society is conditioned to view men as better suited for leadership roles in the business world. Similarly, men face challenges when they step into roles like stay-at-home dads or work in the fashion industry, where their expertise is often questioned. This isn’t confined to gender but extends to other factors like socioeconomic background. While we’ve made progress, change is slow. We can continue to promote acceptance by highlighting the positive attributes of those who defy societal norms without being too forceful. I believe we’re at a good balance where these changes are starting to be accepted. It’s a slow process, but we’re making progress. Discrimination isn’t just about gender; it also involves factors like where you come from and your background.

Understood, they didn't legalize it; they decriminalized it. It's like going from a criminal offense to getting a traffic ticket. Catching someone with a drug charge could lead to job interview ramifications, but the worst ones usually don't disappear when it's decriminalized. There's an argument that arresting and processing people is expensive. It costs a lot to book, house, and process them, and even more to go through court and appoint a public defender. Municipalities might not make these concessions, even if it could free up money for other programs. In places like Denver, where people are more liberal, it's okay. They have more money now for public education, social programs for the elderly, and food programs for the homeless. Marijuana isn't something you want to be everywhere, but there's a financial element to it. If it were totally legal, it could be sold in gas stations, leading to more people smoking and driving under its influence—something that's still taboo in many places. I think marijuana has a more adverse effect on lifestyle than just motor skills. Everyone reacts differently, and some people exercise moderation while others don't. Both substances have their adverse effects, and it's hard to generalize due to differing reactions.

I would say yes, for sure. A lot of the things they do are very traditional, like they've been doing them for a long time. It's good to be rooted in tradition, but it's also essential to be adaptable to change. I guess a lot of Catholics believe they have to go to Church every week and they're quite strict on how things are done. Sometimes, I feel like the Catholic Church looks down on people who don't follow the doctrine to a tee and they don't accept people who aren't exactly perfect Catholics. They also don't accept people of other religions. For example, my dad was an Episcopalian, and my mom was a Catholic, and they wouldn't marry my parents in the Catholic Church because of my dad's religion. That's not really being tolerant of other religions. We always learned to love others, that's a Catholic teaching, but it's hypocritical to say to love others and then to not accept them in that way. So I feel like a lot of Catholic doctrine tells you to do things, but then the Catholic practice goes against it because it's so outdated, but they continue to stick with it anyway. I don't think that would necessarily influence it. I mean, I personally think it would be a good idea to allow priests to marry, but I don't think that would necessarily deter them from their pedophilic behavior. So it might be a different realm, but I probably don't think that would be an issue. Well, I guess people who molest children probably would do that regardless of whether they had a spouse or not, because it's about children, which is different than a spouse. If you're going to do something like that, you're probably going to do it whether or not you're married. I don't think allowing priests to be married would prevent those things from happening. I think that would probably happen regardless. Nope.

Well, I'm still on the fence about this whole debate on marriage. I haven't formed a solid opinion yet, so I can't say who's right or wrong. But I must admit, this is one of the trickiest topics we're facing today, especially when it comes to the separation of church and state and how to define marriage. It's so sensitive that it's hard to discuss without offending someone.

I think all civil unions should be looked at the same way by the government, just like a civil union. If you're married, I believe they should just treat it as a civil union, because that's essentially what it is - two people united. They shouldn't differentiate it based on the type of ceremony or belief system involved.

And as for gay marriage, it's just another form of a civil union, really. If all the states can come to a logical conclusion about this, then it makes sense to push for federal recognition. However, I don't think a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage is necessary or appropriate. It's just not important enough to amend the constitution for such a cause.

I was brought up in a Christian household, so my stance on homosexuality is a bit nuanced for me. I have many gay friends, and while I may not fully agree with their lifestyle, I believe it should be legalized and that it shouldn't be a national issue. I think the decision should be left to each state rather than the president dictating it for the entire country.

Many states are either democratic or republican, and it's clear which side of the issue they lean towards. If you live in a democratic state, you're well aware of its stance on gay marriage. So, if a state decides to legalize it, I don't think you should disagree with that decision, as you chose to live there. I believe homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals, and as such, I think gay marriage should be legalized based on the discretion of each state.

I don't feel as though former President Bush should have decided that the whole country should be against gay marriage. I think it should be up to individual states to decide, as they are the ones who will have to live with the consequences. I don't agree with his ban on it. I don't think he should have the power to dictate how each state runs itself, as he doesn't live in every single state. In the beginning, the war seemed like a good idea to me, especially considering the personal impact of nine eleven. I was all for going over there and creating as much chaos as they did for us. However, I think we overlooked many things and didn't really think about the long-term consequences. We went in unprepared and without a clear plan, and I believe it backfired on us. Now, I'm very much against it. I don't think it accomplished anything. The people over there, they're fighting with each other, and I don't think us being there will stop that. They're just looking to get us out of there, and I think that should be fine. We just need to leave. I think we were more driven by emotion and anger than rational thought. We didn't consider what this could lead to or how they would react to our presence. The president, at the time, was driven by public sentiment and his own desire to act. I understand that, but I think we could have had a better plan. We really didn't know what we were supposed to do to create order. There was no unity or clear purpose. Honestly, I don't think we're the ones to change those people. They're always going to be like that. We're not making enough progress, and I think no matter how long we stay, once we leave, it will collapse. We can't stay there forever. I don't think we're doing ourselves any good by staying there.

In my opinion, the Catholic Church could stand to change in a few areas. They've been losing some of their followers, and I think it's due to their often steadfast views on certain topics. For instance, they have strong views on issues like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control, which can seem outdated in the modern world. If they were to adopt a more contemporary mindset, they might not face the same threat to their following.

I've heard a lot of people are starting to turn away from the Catholic Church because they disagree with their stance on these issues. For example, if someone is pro-abortion, they might not feel comfortable in a faith that views abortion as completely wrong. Similarly, if someone supports gay marriage, they may not want to be part of a church that doesn't agree with that.

I'm not sure why the Catholic Church can't ordain women as priests or allow priests to marry, but I think it would be beneficial for both the Church and its followers. It could help the Church appear more modern and relatable, while also giving priests a more balanced life. However, I'm not convinced that these changes would prevent the abuse scandals that have plagued the Church. It's hard to say if married priests or women priests would have made a difference in those situations. Ultimately, I believe that even with these changes, the Church might still face the same issues.

Well, to be honest with you, I'm not one to argue against gay marriage. I mean, I think that whether someone is born with a certain sexual orientation or they choose it, it's not a conscious decision. Therefore, I believe that gay people shouldn't be held accountable for their sexual orientation. It's just wrong to say that a man and a woman can get married, but two people of the same sex can't. I haven't given this topic much thought, but I'd certainly say it's wrong to make such a distinction. It's not as if being gay is a choice, like being straight is for some people. I mean, I was born straight, and others are born gay, and I don't think that's something they should be held responsible for. I don't think it's a legal or moral issue that the federal government should be involved in. It's not about their security or moral concerns, it's just about being who they are. The federal government has no right to interfere with people's lives, especially if they haven't done anything wrong. That's just how they were born, and they shouldn't be punished for that.

It's my belief that gay marriage ought to be legalized. There really isn't a compelling reason not to. People often assert that same-sex couples pose a threat to traditional families, but it's just not that simple. There are so many variables involved that it's impossible to compare the two situations directly. It's like comparing heads and tails; they might look different, but they're both valid sides of the same coin. Furthermore, numerous civil rights are at stake here, such as property taxes and healthcare benefits where a partner can't be listed as next of kin if they're in a same-sex relationship. This seems unfair if you're committed to someone for life. Scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have similar success rates in relationships as heterosexual couples. They just want the same legal document that any couple can receive from the government, a marriage certificate. Church and state involvement shouldn't be an issue when it comes to legalizing marriage. It's like segregation, separate but unequal. Many people also worry about adoption issues and how children in same-sex families will be treated by society. I believe these concerns are overblown. Perhaps, in some cases, children in same-sex families may face challenges, but parenting skills and community involvement aren't affected by sexual orientation. The federal government should step in and legalize gay marriage across all states. The amendment should be reversed to reflect this. However, President Bush has strong religious views that influence his stance on the subject, similar to his views on abortion and stem cell research. Most of the arguments against gay marriage are based on moral grounds, which vary greatly from person to person. It's unethical to impose the morality of one group on the entire country. Many people believe that gay people are psychologically damaged due to childhood trauma or personality defects, but the American Psychological Association has debunked these claims. It's important to listen to institutions that conduct research rather than popular opinion.

Well, first off, I'm working in a hospital pharmacy over the summer. I mean, just because a drug is illegal doesn't mean it has beneficial properties. I mean, we all know that. Having it available for the public? No, absolutely not. But for medicinal purposes? I'd say yes. Just because a drug is illegal doesn't mean it's beneficial. It's not beneficial. That's the thing. There are so many drugs that are illegal but are beneficial, like oxycodone, Vicodin, Percocets, things like that. Those are controlled substances, but we use them all the time because they're beneficial. If you deny that just because there's a taboo around marijuana, then what's the point? You should embrace its beneficial properties, I think.

I mean, it's not similar to alcohol. If you abuse it, alcohol can lead to bad things. But marijuana, if you abuse it, it's a tough one. I'd say, not that you could integrate it. You could let it become legal gradually, but not all at once, because then it would be abused. You gotta remove that taboo around marijuana first, and then people might use it responsibly. People have such a bad image of marijuana because it's an illegal drug. I mean, it's not that bad for you. It's not like heroine or cocaine. If we get rid of that image of marijuana as a horrible thing, then people might be able to use it responsibly, and certainly for medical purposes.

I believe that the church has adapted to suit the twenty-first century, loosening its strictness. As I grew up, I'd attend church every Sunday, dressed to the nines in cute dresses, matching shoes, and a purse. I went to a private school, where I'd see friends at church on weekends. Now, though, they've introduced a teenager mass that lasts just thirty minutes, and people wear more casual attire, especially during summer when they come straight from the beach. Even at morning masses, I see folks in jeans and khakis. I think the church has become more casual overall. As for other changes, I don't know much about the church's politics, but the biggest thing I've noticed is the change in dress code and the introduction of a shorter mass. [OK, regarding the accusations against Catholic priests, do you think these could have been prevented if the church changed, like allowing female priests or priests to marry?] I don't think these things could have been avoided because there are men who become pedophiles even if they're married. It's more about individual predisposition than rules. If they really wanted to practice their faith and be married, they could consider a different faith. [Can you elaborate on your answer?] I think it's more about genetics influencing sexuality. People are born that way, not just from upbringing. I don't think marriage can change that. If the church knew about it and covered it up, that's shameful, but I don't think they always knew. [Do you have any other thoughts about the Catholic Church?] No.

Initially, I was on board with the initial premise, but I believe everyone was still deeply affected by the September 11th attacks, and I think we went into Iraq under false pretenses. There were several reasons that led us into Iraq, including claims that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which have since been proven false.
I find it utterly infuriating that the Bush administration openly lied to the American people and has yet to take responsibility.
Even Colin Powell, who presented the case at the UN, admits he wasn't convinced by the evidence he was presenting at the time.
To me, that's an impeachable offense. They lied to the American people, and I believe they've shown a complete disregard for the Constitution since the September 11th attacks.
It seems they came into office with an intent to go to war, perhaps driven by a desire to expand our energy supply.
I think the Iraq war has gone on long enough, but I'm concerned that withdrawing now could lead to civil war and more deaths.
The alternative seems to be a coalition of nearby nations like Syria and Saudi Arabia to try to restore order, but I'm not convinced that's a good idea in the long term.
Iraq's sovereignty could become a major issue, as the interim government appears to be dissolving. The Parliament isn't effective, and radical factions are vying for control.

I genuinely believe that it's not right to legalize it or for a state to declare it legal. It should be up to the churches, as the Constitution clearly states our separation of church and state. Trying to enforce any rules or power over it would go against the principles already established in our constitution. I think those pushing for it are pitting one church's beliefs against others, as most Catholics and Christians are against it, except for in certain areas like Boston. It's not up to the government to decide what churches should or shouldn't make illegal. Our constitution already provides for religious tolerance. Making an amendment about it would be wrong and contradictory to what's already been established. Plus, it's one of the few amendments that could be used to restrict the people rather than the government. I don't think the federal government or any government should be involved in this issue. The person pushing for this amendment is doing so because it goes against his personal beliefs as a Catholic. His push for an amendment is showing a preference for one religion over others. I truly believe it's up to the churches to decide this matter, not the president or any government official. There's no valid reason for an amendment banning it, as I don't see how it would impact the economy or society negatively. In fact, it might have a positive impact on society.

The war in Iraq
Well
Let me start from the beginning. I don’t believe the government was completely honest with the American people about the war in Iraq. I think they tried to link the invasion of Iraq to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, even though there wasn't a strong connection. They played on the emotions of the American people, and the invasion started in 2003.

I myself am against war, especially preemptive strikes. I think the war in Iraq is similar to the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes. A tremendous amount of American soldiers have died, and the government wasn't prepared for the aftermath. They removed the Iraqi government and tried to implement a democratic one, a process that should have been carefully planned.

I think the government didn't prepare well for the challenges that would follow, and they didn't account for the massive insurgency that would arise. They should have learned from the Vietnam War, where the US faced a similar challenge. The US government made it seem like victory would be swift and easy, which was naive and deceiving.

In the 2004 presidential election, I would have voted for George Bush to finish what he started, but it's difficult to see how we can abandon Iraq now. We can't leave them without their government anymore. It's a tough decision because we’ve been there for so long and there are so many American casualties. But how much is too much to risk for a free democratic Iraq?

Another consideration is why we're not doing this in other countries. It seems to be about oil, and we get oil from Iraq. The government's justification for the war was about weapons of mass destruction, but they were never found. Meanwhile, North Korea has them, and we aren't making any attacks against them. I don't think the US government is being thorough or truthful enough in their decisions.

I just hope the war ends soon and brings peace, but I doubt it.

Let's dive right in. I've always been an advocate for gay marriage, and I believe it should be a personal preference, not something that society or the government should interfere with. I think it's inhumane to deny people rights based on something they have no control over, especially when science shows it might be biological rather than sociological. In my neighborhood, I have a few openly gay couples who live together, and they function just like any other family. They walk their dogs on the street, and it's clear they're happy and loving. But the government, particularly with Bush trying to interpret marriage his way, is being ridiculous. It's like they're trying to play God. I think marriage should be a private, personal matter, not something that needs to be in the public's eye or dictated by the government. It's strange that a guy and a girl can get married in secret in Las Vegas, but if two gay people want to do the same, it makes the news. That's not fair.

You know, when you put something online, it's out there for the world to see. It's a public forum, and you can't control what people think or do with that information. As a Resident Assistant, I've had to deal with this already. When you share something online, it's like you're shouting it from the rooftops. You can't just share any information without thinking about the consequences.

For instance, if you're talking about something dangerous, like blowing something up or planning shootings, someone will definitely take notice. The internet is seen by everyone, so if you're friends with someone on Myspace, they'll see it. Obviously, the school isn't looking at these things, but someone in the community might notice and bring it to the school's attention.

There's no invasion of privacy when something is brought to the school's attention. If you don't want something to be seen, don't put it online. You can't tell people what to think or take seriously. The school officials aren't supposed to be monitoring phone conversations, texts, or IM's, but if something is brought to their attention, they have to take it seriously.

For example, a few months ago, someone overheard something in the school and got worried. They went through the person's Facebook and found something that was meant as a joke but became serious in light of the situation. If something is brought to the school's attention, there's no invasion of privacy, because the information was made public.

Teachers shouldn't be creating accounts under different names and becoming friends with their students. I wouldn't friend my residents on Facebook for the same reason. I don't want to see what they're doing or posting, like going out and drinking. If it's brought to their attention, though, the school has to take it seriously.

I feel like the war has been dragged out far too long. I think the original intent was noble, aiming to restore democracy in another country. However, I believe we've strayed from that purpose. Now, it seems like we're just fighting to prove our status as a superpower. The initial motivations were questionable, involving previous tensions between George Bush Sr. and Saddam Hussein. If the goal was to democratize a country with an unfair political system, that would be a valid reason for the war. However, I think our original objectives have become distorted, and we're now stuck in a conflict with an unclear endgame. We're still at war, not because we must, but because we don't want to retreat without a decisive victory. It's been drawn out for too long. The government there now needs to stand on its own, and we should focus on our own economic struggles. We're spending billions that could be better used on our own issues, like poverty and public infrastructure. The war is a long-term drain on our economy, and there are pressing domestic issues that need our attention. It's time to bring our troops home.

I certainly believe that gender discrimination remains a significant issue in the United States. It’s not just about women; it extends to various fields of work. For instance, women often struggle to ascend to positions that they qualify for, as society is conditioned to view men as better suited for leadership roles in the business world. Similarly, men face challenges when they step into roles like stay-at-home dads or work in the fashion industry, where their expertise is often questioned. This isn’t confined to gender but extends to other factors like socioeconomic background. While we’ve made progress, change is slow. We can continue to promote acceptance by highlighting the positive attributes of those who defy societal norms without being too forceful. I believe we’re at a good balance where these changes are starting to be accepted. It’s a slow process, but we’re making progress. Discrimination isn’t just about gender; it also involves factors like where you come from and your background.

Understood, they didn't legalize it; they decriminalized it. It's like going from a criminal offense to getting a traffic ticket. Catching someone with a drug charge could lead to job interview ramifications, but the worst ones usually don't disappear when it's decriminalized. There's an argument that arresting and processing people is expensive. It costs a lot to book, house, and process them, and even more to go through court and appoint a public defender. Municipalities might not make these concessions, even if it could free up money for other programs. In places like Denver, where people are more liberal, it's okay. They have more money now for public education, social programs for the elderly, and food programs for the homeless. Marijuana isn't something you want to be everywhere, but there's a financial element to it. If it were totally legal, it could be sold in gas stations, leading to more people smoking and driving under its influence—something that's still taboo in many places. I think marijuana has a more adverse effect on lifestyle than just motor skills. Everyone reacts differently, and some people exercise moderation while others don't. Both substances have their adverse effects, and it's hard to generalize due to differing reactions.

I would say yes, for sure. A lot of the things they do are very traditional, like they've been doing them for a long time. It's good to be rooted in tradition, but it's also essential to be adaptable to change. I guess a lot of Catholics believe they have to go to Church every week and they're quite strict on how things are done. Sometimes, I feel like the Catholic Church looks down on people who don't follow the doctrine to a tee and they don't accept people who aren't exactly perfect Catholics. They also don't accept people of other religions. For example, my dad was an Episcopalian, and my mom was a Catholic, and they wouldn't marry my parents in the Catholic Church because of my dad's religion. That's not really being tolerant of other religions. We always learned to love others, that's a Catholic teaching, but it's hypocritical to say to love others and then to not accept them in that way. So I feel like a lot of Catholic doctrine tells you to do things, but then the Catholic practice goes against it because it's so outdated, but they continue to stick with it anyway. I don't think that would necessarily influence it. I mean, I personally think it would be a good idea to allow priests to marry, but I don't think that would necessarily deter them from their pedophilic behavior. So it might be a different realm, but I probably don't think that would be an issue. Well, I guess people who molest children probably would do that regardless of whether they had a spouse or not, because it's about children, which is different than a spouse. If you're going to do something like that, you're probably going to do it whether or not you're married. I don't think allowing priests to be married would prevent those things from happening. I think that would probably happen regardless. Nope.

Well, I'm still on the fence about this whole debate on marriage. I haven't formed a solid opinion yet, so I can't say who's right or wrong. But I must admit, this is one of the trickiest topics we're facing today, especially when it comes to the separation of church and state and how to define marriage. It's so sensitive that it's hard to discuss without offending someone.

I think all civil unions should be looked at the same way by the government, just like a civil union. If you're married, I believe they should just treat it as a civil union, because that's essentially what it is - two people united. They shouldn't differentiate it based on the type of ceremony or belief system involved.

And as for gay marriage, it's just another form of a civil union, really. If all the states can come to a logical conclusion about this, then it makes sense to push for federal recognition. However, I don't think a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage is necessary or appropriate. It's just not important enough to amend the constitution for such a cause.

I was brought up in a Christian household, so my stance on homosexuality is a bit nuanced for me. I have many gay friends, and while I may not fully agree with their lifestyle, I believe it should be legalized and that it shouldn't be a national issue. I think the decision should be left to each state rather than the president dictating it for the entire country.

Many states are either democratic or republican, and it's clear which side of the issue they lean towards. If you live in a democratic state, you're well aware of its stance on gay marriage. So, if a state decides to legalize it, I don't think you should disagree with that decision, as you chose to live there. I believe homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals, and as such, I think gay marriage should be legalized based on the discretion of each state.

I don't feel as though former President Bush should have decided that the whole country should be against gay marriage. I think it should be up to individual states to decide, as they are the ones who will have to live with the consequences. I don't agree with his ban on it. I don't think he should have the power to dictate how each state runs itself, as he doesn't live in every single state. Plus, he's leaving office soon, and if a democratic president decides to lift the ban, it will just go back and forth. I believe that some things should be left up to each individual state, as they are the ones who will be most affected by their decision.

In the beginning, the war seemed like a good idea to me, especially considering the personal impact of nine eleven. I was all for going over there and creating as much chaos as they did for us. However, I think we overlooked many things and didn't really think about the long-term consequences. We went in unprepared and without a clear plan, and I believe it backfired on us. Now, I'm very much against it. I don't think it accomplished anything. The people over there, they're fighting with each other, and I don't think us being there will stop that. They're just looking to get us out of there, and I think that should be fine. We just need to leave. I think we were more driven by emotion and anger than rational thought. We didn't consider what this could lead to or how they would react to our presence. The president, at the time, was driven by public sentiment and his own desire to act. I understand that, but I think we could have had a better plan. We really didn't know what we were supposed to do to create order. There was no unity or clear purpose. Honestly, I don't think we're the ones to change those people. They're always going to be like that. We're not making enough progress, and I think no matter how long we stay, once we leave, it will collapse. We can't stay there forever. I don't think we're doing ourselves any good by staying there.

In my opinion, the Catholic Church could stand to change in a few areas. They've been losing some of their followers, and I think it's due to their often steadfast views on certain topics. For instance, they have strong views on issues like gay marriage, abortion, and birth control, which can seem outdated in the modern world. If they were to adopt a more contemporary mindset, they might not face the same threat to their following.

I've heard a lot of people are starting to turn away from the Catholic Church because they disagree with their stance on these issues. For example, if someone is pro-abortion, they might not feel comfortable in a faith that views abortion as completely wrong. Similarly, if someone supports gay marriage, they may not want to be part of a church that doesn't agree with that.

I'm not sure why the Catholic Church can't ordain women as priests or allow priests to marry, but I think it would be beneficial for both the Church and its followers. It could help the Church appear more modern and relatable, while also giving priests a more balanced life. However, I'm not convinced that these changes would prevent the abuse scandals that have plagued the Church. It's hard to say if married priests or women priests would have made a difference in those situations. Ultimately, I believe that even with these changes, the Church might still face the same issues.

Well, to be honest with you, I'm not one to argue against gay marriage. I mean, I think that whether someone is born with a certain sexual orientation or they choose it, it's not a conscious decision. Therefore, I believe that gay people shouldn't be held accountable for their sexual orientation. It's just wrong to say that a man and a woman can get married, but two people of the same sex can't. I haven't given this topic much thought, but I'd certainly say it's wrong to make such a distinction. It's not as if being gay is a choice, like being straight is for some people. I mean, I was born straight, and others are born gay, and I don't think that's something they should be held responsible for. I don't think it's a legal or moral issue that the federal government should be involved in. It's not about their security or moral concerns, it's just about being who they are. The federal government has no right to interfere with people's lives, especially if they haven't done anything wrong. That's just how they were born, and they shouldn't be punished for that.

It's my belief that gay marriage ought to be legalized. There really isn't a compelling reason not to. People often assert that same-sex couples pose a threat to traditional families, but it's just not that simple. There are so many variables involved that it's impossible to compare the two situations directly. It's like comparing heads and tails; they might look different, but they're both valid sides of the same coin. Furthermore, numerous civil rights are at stake here, such as property taxes and healthcare benefits where a partner can't be listed as next of kin if they're in a same-sex relationship. This seems unfair if you're committed to someone for life. Scientific studies have shown that homosexual couples have similar success rates in relationships as heterosexual couples. They just want the same legal document that any couple can receive from the government, a marriage certificate. Church and state involvement shouldn't be an issue when it comes to legalizing marriage. It's like segregation, separate but unequal. Many people also worry about adoption issues and how children in same-sex families will be treated by society. I believe these concerns are overblown. Perhaps, in some cases, children in same-sex families may face challenges, but parenting skills and community involvement aren't affected by sexual orientation. The federal government should step in and legalize gay marriage across all states. The amendment should be reversed to reflect this. However, President Bush has strong religious views that influence his stance on the subject, similar to his views on abortion and stem cell research. Most of the arguments against gay marriage are based on moral grounds, which vary greatly from person to person. It's unethical to impose the morality of one group on the entire country. Many people believe that gay people are psychologically damaged due to childhood trauma or personality defects, but the American Psychological Association has debunked these claims. It's important to listen to institutions that conduct research rather than popular opinion.

Well, first off, I'm working in a hospital pharmacy over the summer. I mean, just because a drug is illegal doesn't mean it has beneficial properties. I mean, we all know that. Having it available for the public? No, absolutely not. But for medicinal purposes? I'd say yes. Just because a drug is illegal doesn't mean it's beneficial. It's not beneficial. That's the thing. There are so many drugs that are illegal but are beneficial, like oxycodone, Vicodin, Percocets, things like that. Those are controlled substances, but we use them all the time because they're beneficial. If you deny that just because there's a taboo around marijuana, then what's the point? You should embrace its beneficial properties, I think.

I mean, it's not similar to alcohol. If you abuse it, alcohol can lead to bad things. But marijuana, if you abuse it, it's a tough one. I'd say, not that you could integrate it. You could let it become legal gradually, but not all at once, because then it would be abused. You gotta remove that taboo around marijuana first, and then people might use it responsibly. People have such a bad image of marijuana because it's an illegal drug. I mean, it's not that bad for you. It's not like heroine or cocaine. If we get rid of that image of marijuana as a horrible thing, then people might be able to use it responsibly, and certainly for medical purposes.

I believe that the church has adapted to suit the twenty-first century, loosening its strictness. As I grew up, I'd attend church every Sunday, dressed to the nines in cute dresses, matching shoes, and a purse. I went to a private school, where I'd see friends at church on weekends. Now, though, they've introduced a teenager mass that lasts just thirty minutes, and people wear more casual attire, especially during summer when they come straight from the beach. Even at morning masses, I see folks in jeans and khakis. I think the church has become more casual overall. As for other changes, I don't know much about the church's politics, but the biggest thing I've noticed is the change in dress code and the introduction of a shorter mass. [OK, regarding the accusations against Catholic priests, do you think these could have been prevented if the church changed, like allowing female priests or priests to marry?] I don't think these things could have been avoided because there are men who become pedophiles even if they're married. It's more about individual predisposition than rules. If they really wanted to practice their faith and be married, they could consider a different faith. [Can you elaborate on your answer?] I think it's more about genetics influencing sexuality. People are born that way, not just from upbringing. I don't think marriage can change that. If the church knew about it and covered it up, that's shameful, but I don't think they always knew. [Do you have any other thoughts about the Catholic Church?] No.

Initially, I was on board with the initial premise, but I believe everyone was still deeply affected by the September 11th attacks, and I think we went into Iraq under false pretenses. There were several reasons that led us into Iraq, including claims that Saddam Hussein had weapons of mass destruction, which have since been proven false.
I find it utterly infuriating that the Bush administration openly lied to the American people and has yet to take responsibility.
Even Colin Powell, who presented the case at the UN, admits he wasn't convinced by the evidence he was presenting at the time.
To me, that's an impeachable offense. They lied to the American people, and I believe they've shown a complete disregard for the Constitution since the September 11th attacks.
It seems they came into office with an intent to go to war, perhaps driven by a desire to expand our energy supply.
I think the Iraq war has gone on long enough, but I'm concerned that withdrawing now could lead to civil war and more deaths.
The alternative seems to be a coalition of nearby nations like Syria and Saudi Arabia to try to restore order, but I'm not convinced that's a good idea in the long term.
Iraq's sovereignty could become a major issue, as the interim government appears to be dissolving. The Parliament isn't effective, and radical factions are vying for control.

I genuinely believe that it's not right to legalize it or for a state to declare it legal. It should be up to the churches, as the Constitution clearly states our separation of church and state. Trying to enforce any rules or power over it would go against the principles already established in our constitution. I think those pushing for it are pitting one church's beliefs against others, as most Catholics and Christians are against it, except for in certain areas like Boston. It's not up to the government to decide what churches should or shouldn't make illegal. Our constitution already provides for religious tolerance. Making an amendment about it would be wrong and contradictory to what's already been established. Plus, it's one of the few amendments that could be used to restrict the people rather than the government. I don't think the federal government or any government should be involved in this issue. The person pushing for this amendment is doing so because it goes against his personal beliefs as a Catholic. His push for an amendment is showing a preference for one religion over others. I truly believe it's up to the churches to decide this matter, not the president or any government official. There's no valid reason for an amendment banning it, as I don't see how it would impact the economy or society negatively. In fact, it might have a positive impact on society.

The war in Iraq
Well
Let me start from the beginning. I don’t believe the government was completely honest with the American people about the war in Iraq. I think they tried to link the invasion of Iraq to the terrorist attacks of September 11th, even though there wasn't a strong connection. They played on the emotions of the American people, and the invasion started in 2003.

I myself am against war, especially preemptive strikes. I think the war in Iraq is similar to the Vietnam War, and the government should have learned from past mistakes. A tremendous amount of American soldiers have died, and the government wasn't prepared for the aftermath. They removed the Iraqi government and tried to implement a democratic one, a process that should have been carefully planned.

I think the government didn't prepare well for the challenges that would follow, and they didn't account for the massive insurgency that would arise. They should have learned from the Vietnam War, where the US faced a similar challenge. The US government made it seem like victory would be swift and easy, which was naive and deceiving.

In the 2004 presidential election, I would have voted for George Bush to finish what he started, but it's difficult to see how we can abandon Iraq now. We can't leave them without their government anymore. It's a tough decision because we’ve been there for so long and there are so many American casualties. But how much is too much to risk for a free democratic Iraq?

Another consideration is why we're not doing this in other countries. It seems to be about oil, and we get oil from Iraq. The government's justification for the war was about weapons of mass destruction, but they were never found. Meanwhile, North Korea has them, and we aren't making any attacks against them. I don't think the US government is being thorough or truthful enough in their decisions.

I just hope the war ends soon and brings peace, but I doubt it.

Let's dive right in. I've always been an advocate for gay marriage, and I believe it should be a personal preference, not something that society or the government should interfere with. I think it's inhumane to deny people rights based on something they have no control over, especially when science shows it might be biological rather than sociological. In my neighborhood, I have a few openly gay couples who live together, and they function just like any other family. They walk their dogs on the street, and it's clear they're happy and loving. But the government, particularly with Bush trying to interpret marriage his way, is being ridiculous. It's like they're trying to play God. I think marriage should be a private, personal matter, not something that needs to be in the public's eye or dictated by the government. It's strange that a guy and a girl can get married in secret in Las Vegas, but if two gay people want to do the same, it makes the news. That's not fair.

You know, when you put something online, it's out there for the world to see. It's a public forum, and you can't control what people think or do with that information. As a Resident Assistant, I've had to deal with this already. When you share something online, it's like you're shouting it from the rooftops. You can't just share any information without thinking about the consequences.

For instance, if you're talking about something dangerous, like blowing something up or planning shootings, someone will definitely take notice. The internet is seen by everyone, so if you're friends with someone on Myspace, they'll see it. Obviously, the school isn't looking at these things, but someone in the community might notice and bring it to the school's attention.

There's no invasion of privacy when something is brought to the school's attention. If you don't want something to be seen, don't put it online. You can't tell people what to think or take seriously. The school officials aren't supposed to be monitoring phone conversations, texts, or IM's, but if something is brought to their attention, they have to take it seriously.

For example, a few months ago, someone overheard something in the school and got worried. They went through the person's Facebook and found something that was meant as a joke but became serious in light of the situation. If something is brought to the school's attention, there's no invasion of privacy, because the information was made public.

Teachers shouldn't be creating accounts under different names and becoming friends with their students. I wouldn't friend my residents on Facebook for the same reason. I don't want to see what they're doing or posting, like going out and drinking. If it's brought to their attention, though, the school has to take it seriously.

I feel like the war has been dragged out far too long. I think the original intent was noble, aiming to restore democracy in another country. However, I believe we've strayed from that purpose. Now, it seems like we're just fighting to prove our status as a superpower. The initial motivations were questionable, involving previous tensions between George Bush Sr. and Saddam Hussein. If the goal was to democratize a country with an unfair political system, that would be a valid reason for the war. However, I think our original objectives have become distorted, and we're now stuck in a conflict with an unclear endgame. We're still at war, not because we must, but because we don't want to retreat without a decisive victory. It's been drawn out for too long. The government there now needs to stand on its own, and we should focus on our own economic struggles. We're spending billions that could be better used on our own issues, like poverty and public infrastructure. The war is a long-term drain on our economy, and there are pressing domestic issues that need our attention. It's time to bring our troops home.

I certainly believe that gender discrimination remains a significant issue in the United States. It’s not just about women; it extends to various fields of work. For instance, women often struggle to ascend to positions that they qualify for, as society is conditioned to view men as better suited for leadership roles in the business world. Similarly, men face challenges when they step into roles like stay-at-home dads or work in the fashion industry, where their expertise is often questioned. This isn’t confined to gender but extends to other factors like socioeconomic background. While we’ve made progress, change is slow. We can continue to promote acceptance by highlighting the positive attributes of those who defy societal norms without being too forceful. I believe we’re at a good balance where these changes are starting to be accepted. It’s a slow process, but we’re making progress. Discrimination isn’t just about gender; it also involves factors like where you come from and your background.

Understood, they didn't legalize it; they decriminalized it. It's like going from a criminal offense to getting a traffic ticket. Catching someone with a drug charge could lead to job interview ramifications, but the worst ones usually don't disappear when it's decriminalized. There's an argument that arresting and processing people is expensive. It costs a lot to book, house, and process them, and even more to go through court and appoint a public defender. Municipalities might not make these concessions, even if it could free up money for other programs. In places like Denver, where people are more liberal, it's okay. They have more money now for public education, social programs for the elderly, and food programs for the homeless. Marijuana isn't something you want to be everywhere, but there's a financial element to it. If it were totally legal, it could be sold in gas stations, leading to more people smoking and driving under its influence—something that's still taboo in many places. I think marijuana has a more adverse effect on lifestyle than just motor skills. Everyone reacts differently, and some people exercise moderation while others don't. Both substances have their adverse effects, and it's hard to generalize due to differing reactions.

I would say yes, for sure. A lot of the things they do are very traditional, like they've been doing them for a long time. It's good to be rooted in tradition, but it's also essential to be adaptable to change. I guess a lot of Catholics believe they have to go to Church every week and they're quite strict on how things are done. Sometimes, I feel like the Catholic Church looks down on people who don't follow the doctrine to a tee and they don't accept people who aren't exactly perfect Catholics. They also don't accept people of other religions. For example, my dad was an Episcopalian, and my mom was a Catholic, and they wouldn't marry my parents in the Catholic Church because of my dad's religion. That's not really being tolerant of other religions. We always learned to love others, that's a Catholic teaching, but it's hypocritical to say to love others and then to not accept them in that way. So I feel like a lot of Catholic doctrine tells you to do things, but then the Catholic practice goes against it because it's so outdated, but they continue to stick with it anyway. I don't think that would necessarily influence it. I mean, I personally think it would be a good idea to allow priests to marry, but I don't think that would necessarily deter them from their pedophilic behavior. So it might be a different realm, but I probably don't think that would be an issue. Well, I guess people who molest children probably would do that regardless of whether they had a spouse or not, because it's about children, which is different than a spouse. If you're going to do something like that, you're probably going to do it whether or not you're married. I don't think allowing priests to be married would prevent those things from happening. I think that would probably happen regardless. Nope.

Well, I'm still on the fence about this whole debate on marriage. I haven't formed a solid opinion yet, so I can't say who's right or wrong. But I must admit, this is one of the trickiest topics we're facing today, especially when it comes to the separation of church and state and how to define marriage. It's so sensitive that it's hard to discuss without offending someone.

I think all civil unions should be looked at the same way by the government, just like a civil union. If you're married, I believe they should just treat it as a civil union, because that's essentially what it is - two people united. They shouldn't differentiate it based on the type of ceremony or belief system involved.

And as for gay marriage, it's just another form of a civil union, really. If all the states can come to a logical conclusion about this, then it makes sense to push for federal recognition. However, I don't think a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage is necessary or appropriate. It's just not important enough to amend the constitution for such a cause.

I was brought up in a Christian household, so my stance on homosexuality is a bit nuanced for me. I have many gay friends, and while I may not fully agree with their lifestyle, I believe it should be legalized and that it shouldn't be a national issue. I think the decision should be left to each state rather than the president dictating it for the entire country.

Many states are either democratic or republican, and it's clear which side of the issue they lean towards. If you live in a democratic state, you're well aware of its stance on gay marriage. So, if a state decides to legalize it, I don't think you should disagree with that decision, as you chose to live there. I believe homosexuals should have the same opportunities as heterosexuals, and as such, I think gay marriage should be legalized based on the discretion of each state.

I don't feel as though former President Bush should have decided that the whole country should be against gay marriage. I think it should be up to individual states to decide, as they are the ones who will have to live with the consequences. I don't agree with his ban on it. I don't think he should have the power to dictate how each state runs itself, as he doesn't live in every single state. Plus, he's leaving office soon, and if a democratic president decides to lift the ban, it will just go back and forth. I believe that some things should be left up to each individual state, as they are the ones who will be most affected by their decision.

In the beginning, the war seemed like a good idea to me, especially considering the personal impact of nine eleven. I was all for going over there and creating as much chaos as they did for us. However, I think we overlooked many things and didn't really think about the long-term consequences. We went in unprepared and without a clear plan, and I believe it backfired on us. Now, I'm very much against it. I don't think it accomplished anything. The people over there, they're fighting with each other, and I don't think us being there will stop that. They're just looking to get us out of there, and I think that should be fine. We just need to leave. I think we were more driven by emotion and anger than rational thought. We didn't consider what this could lead to or how they would react to our presence. The president, at the time, was driven by public sentiment and his own desire to act. I understand that, but I think we could have had a better plan. We really didn't know what we were supposed to do to create order. There was no unity or clear purpose. Honestly, I don't think we're the ones to change those people. They're always going to be like that. We're not making enough progress, and I think no matter how long we stay, once we leave, it will collapse. We can't stay there forever. I don't think we're doing ourselves any good by staying there.
